Award.AwardTitle: The role of endoderm in cardiac morphogenesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Name: Fang Lin
Proposal number: IOS-1354457
Proposal title: The role of endoderm in cardiac morphogenesis

During vertebrate heart development, a key conserved step is the migration of two bilateral populations of myocardial precursors towards the embryonic midline, where they merge to form the primitive heart tube- the foundation of heart development. This migration is highly regulated and requires interactions between the migrating myocardial precursors and their microenvironment, which includes the adjacent endoderm. However, the mechanisms enabling endoderm to promote myocardial migration are unclear. The Principal Investigator's lab has identified a signaling pathway that is critical for migration of the endodermal tissue layer and the myocardial precursors. In this project, they will apply their expertise in zebrafish genetics, GPCR signaling, and in vivo imaging, and use established tools to dissect the interactions between the endoderm and myocardial precursors. This study is expected to lead to a clear understanding of how the endoderm regulates myocardial migration, which may be broadly applicable to other species. This contribution will be significant in that it will establish a framework for the interplay between the endoderm and myocardial precursors during vertebrate heart development, and provide insights into the mechanisms whereby tissue interactions influence organ development. The knowledge gained from this study will help us to understand how the heart develops.

The zebrafish represents not only a valuable research model, but also an excellent teaching tool for students at all levels. The zebrafish embryo is transparent and develops externally, making it possible to observe developmental processes, including heart development, through a simple stereomicroscope. Thus, zebrafish provides a deliverable classroom-based learning opportunity. The PI is passionate about bringing science to the classroom, inspiring new generations, and promoting an awareness of basic biological research among the public. She believes that these efforts have a positive impact on society. The PI will continue to conduct outreach educational projects at local K-12 schools, to provide undergraduates with research experience, and to contribute to graduate and postdoctoral fellowship training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

A key event during cardiac development in vertebrates is the migration of populations of myocardial precursors from the left and right sides of the embryo toward the so-called “midline”. There, they form the primitive heart tube—a structure that serves as the foundation for subsequent development of the heart. This migration is highly regulated and requires interactions between neighboring cells of distinct origin: the myocardial precursor cells and endodermal cells. The latter form an underlying sheet, and the mechanisms that enable this structure to promote myocardial migration are unclear.

We have identified a signaling pathway that is critical for the movement of both endodermal cells and myocardial precursors toward the embryonic midline. Our imaging of newly generated zebrafish strains in which the myocardial and endodermal cells are labeled with distinct fluorescent proteins has revealed details of the intricate interplay between these two cell populations, as well as those between the endoderm and the endocardial precursor cells that ultimately form the inner layer of the heart, during heart development. Our results demonstrate that midline migration of the endodermal cells (a process is known as endoderm convergence) regulates the synchronized migration of myocardial and endocardial precursor cells, explaining why changes in the structure of the endodermal sheet are essential for heart development. The knowledge gained from our study not only advances our understanding of how the heart develops but also provides insights into the mechanisms whereby interactions between distinct tissue types influence organ development. Importantly, this knowledge is broadly applicable to other species because cardiac development is highly conserved across vertebrate species.

Our studies have also identified cellular behaviors that contribute to the migration of endodermal cells, as well as several signaling pathways that are involved in regulating this process. We have found that among these pathways one regulates the activation of myosin, which acts as a motor that drives cell movement, while the anterior region of the endoderm converges toward the midline. Thus, our study has uncovered cellular and molecular mechanisms that control endoderm migration—an understudied process that is key to heart development.

 

Broader Impacts:

During the past four years, funding from the NSF has supported the PI in using zebrafish as a platform for promoting science education at multiple levels, as described below. These efforts have inspired a passion for science with a positive impact on society in a new generation. The related activities are described below.

  • Mentoring of trainees: This project has provided topics of study for three postdoctoral fellows, one graduate student, and 10 undergraduates. Two of the postdoctoral fellows now hold independent positions at academic institutions. The third continues to work in the PI’s laboratory, as does the graduate student (will graduate next year). Among the 10 undergraduates who have worked on this project, 5 were recipients of ICRU (Iowa Center for Research by Undergraduates) Research Fellow Awards in support of their independent study. An additional student conducted his honors thesis work on an aspect of this project and was awarded an AHA Undergraduate Summer Research Fellowship for this (summer 2016). Among the 10 students: 7 have graduated; 1 is a graduate student in biomedical research, and 2 are enrolled in medical school.
  • Dissemination of results to the science community: The PI and members of her laboratory regularly present results from this project at national and international scientific meetings. Four papers based on results from this project have been published in highly reputable, peer-reviewed journals. Two additional manuscripts are in preparation for publication.
  • Dissemination of results to students at graduate and college levels: The PI regularly gives presentations to recruit incoming graduate students and as part of a seminar series for undergraduate students who participate in summer research at the University of Iowa. Furthermore, she uses images, movies and other results in teaching graduate courses; because it is obtained directly through cutting-edge laboratory research, this content is greatly appreciated by the students.
  • Dissemination of results to K-12 community. The PI disseminates her research findings to local public schools at both the middle and high school levels via seminars and demonstrations of experiments. In addition, she distributes materials and educational knowledge to empower science teachers and offers laboratory tours to students. The PI and members of her laboratory have also conducted “Zebrafish-in-the-Classroom” summer workshops for science teachers.
